abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Development Board (BWDB) Small
            Schemes Project for Bangladesh achieved a marginally
            satisfactory overall outcome. Impressive gains in production
            were delayed by the construction program and are now
            threatened by deficiencies in operations and maintenance.
            Sustainability of the increased production is uncertain, and
            is contingent on removal of severe risks to the completed
            infrastructure. Institutional development is rated as
            negligible, reflecting the multiple operations and
            maintenance activities promoted at appraisal and then
            largely ignored. The Bank's performance was generally
            satisfactory. The project was well defined and possessed the
            required framework and guidelines for implementation.
            However, implementation and operation of subprojects
            suffered from shortcomings in project design. The
            Bank's supervision missions made positive contributions
            to the physical and institutional development of the
            project. The Borrower's performance in carrying out its
            obligations was below expectations. The chief weakness was
            the persistent failure in timely acquisition of land for
            construction and adequate provision of counterpart funds
            when required. The main lessons learned are: (i) problems of
            land acquisition should be anticipated, and fair and orderly
            compensation measures planned in advance; (ii) the
            construction program should be tailored to a realistic
            projection of resources available to the Government; and
            (iii) the Government must fulfill its commitments to carry
            out regular operations and maintenance, supported by the
            beneficiaries, otherwise the civil works will fail and the
            benefits will be unsustained.
